Award.AwardTitle: Dimensions: Collaborative Research: Symbiont and Transcriptomic Niche Dimensions of Long-term Coexistence in Trifolium Communities
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding how species coexist, and the role of genetic diversity within and between species, remains a fundamental challenge in biodiversity research. This project focuses on highly diverse communities of clover plants and their bacterial nitrogen-fixing symbionts, rhizobia. Integrating observational approaches, manipulative field, greenhouse, and growth chamber experiments, genomic techniques and phylogenetic analyses, this project will test the importance of rhizobial symbionts and soil feedbacks in coexistence. Gene expression and functional traits will serve as proxies for the ecological niche; this project will determine how these evolve using phylogenetic trees that capture the evolutionary history of species. This project will yield an integrated insight into the molecular, functional, and ecological mechanisms of diversity maintenance and will greatly increase our understanding of biological nitrogen fixation, a critical function of legumes and rhizobia in natural and agricultural ecosystems.

Symbiotic nitrogen fixation has global importance on par with photosynthesis, and this project will assess its functionality in light of genetic variation in symbionts and clover species. This project will train two post-docs and two graduate students and will provide research experiences to undergraduate students through the Plant Genomics at MSU program, and through an exchange program with Howard University at UC Davis. The project will train students in the High School Honors Science Program at MSU and in the Ecological Society of America?s SEEDS program (Strategies for Ecology Education, Diversity and Sustainability: Diverse People for a Diverse Science).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding how species coexist, and the effects of genetic and species diversity on coexistence, remains a fundamental challenge in the study of biodiversity. This project focused on highly diverse communities of the legume Trifolium, or clovers. Taking advantage of an existing data set, and building it over the course of this award, we now have a nearly 20-yr record of coexistence of clover species in hundreds of 4m2 plots in nature. We can use these data to understand mechanisms that predict coexistence of species, and the role of nitrogen-fixing bacterial symbionts called rhizobia in this process. 

Combining observational approaches, manipulative field, greenhouse, and growth chamber experiments and genomic techniques, we were able to dissect mechanisms– explored through plant relationships with rhizobial symbionts and soil communities  – that enable coexistence. We also used transcriptomic techniques that tracked which clover genes were turned on and off under different competition treatments, competing clover plants with members of the same or different species of clover.

Our greenhouse experiments manipulated the identiity of clover species and the strains of rhizobia they associated with. These combinations were then competed with other clover-strain combinations. The outcomes of our experiments were able to predict the record of long-term coexistence of clover species in the field.  

In the field, fine-scale sampling of soil communities and soil nutrient profiles also revealed fine-scale habitat variation that allowed species to specialize on somewhat different soil conditions. Such specialization increased rates of coexistence and diversity.

Finally, we have developed new theory to understand how mutualistic relationships (mutually beneficial relationships) between clovers and rhizobia might provide different mechanisms allowing coexistence and increased biodiversity than those models considering only resource competition.

This work has yielded an integrated insight into the molecular, functional, and ecological mechanisms of diversity maintenance. Because rhizobia fix nitrogen, our results also contribute to the understanding of biological nitrogen fixation, a critical role of legumes in natural and agricultural ecosystems.

We have trained 5 graduate students, 4 technicians, who went on to become graduate students in science or science primary school teachers, and many undergraduates. We have also trained 3 postdocs who currently have positions doing science.

 

Many of our results are reported in articles in open access journals available to the public.
